awd_titl_txt: Computer Simulations of G-proteins and Molecular Machines
awd_abstract_narration:
The understanding of how active processes in the cell govern and control major biological functions, such as signaling and molecular motors, is a central question in biophysics.  For example, a detailed understanding is needed of the control and mediation of life processes by G-proteins, where complexes of these proteins with their cofactors regulate signal transduction and transport processes in the cell.  Similarly, it is important to understand how ATP is used to fuel biological machines and control key cellular processes.  A detailed understanding is also needed for the origin of the directional motions of biological motors that generate forces in muscular, cardiac and neural cells.  Progress in understanding these processes require a close interaction between theory and experiment.  This project aims to elucidate how biological molecules control cellular function at the molecular level using state of the art computational approaches using experimental data to validate the findings. Outcomes of this project will be disseminated via general scientific lectures and outreach activities.  In addition, simulation packages will be made available to the scientific community.  

Powerful multiscale models, including quantum mechanics/molecular mechanics (QM/MM) approaches for exploring chemical processes in G-proteins and coarse grained models for studies of energy transduction have been previously developed by the investigator and his research group.  Such developments will now be used to quantify the chemical and conformational coupling in the motor protein F1-ATPase and to explore the force generation in myosin and its relationship to muscles action. In addition, the allosteric activation process of GPCRs and its effect on the binding of GDP and GTP to G-proteins, as well as the action of EF-Tu and EF-G, which play major role in controlling the ribosome function, will be explored.  The detailed quantitative understanding resulting from this project is likely to have a strong impact on advancing fundamental biological knowledge, as well as having potential biomedical implications.

por.por_cntn:
Overview – Tremendous advances in the understanding of the molecular basis of human health have emerged in the past few decades. However, detailed quantitative understanding is still critical. For example, understanding the control and mediation of life processes by G-Proteins is needed, where the complexes of these proteins with their cofactors regulate signal transduction and transport processes. Similarly important is the understanding of the use of ATP in specialized proteins to fuel biological machines and to control key processes. A related issue that requires detailed understanding is the problem of directional motions of biological motors that generate directional force in muscular, cardiac, and neural cells that are often involved in diseases due to faulty functions. Additionally, understanding the action of  G proteins coupled receptors (GPCRs ) is crucial for having a clearer view about how external factors such, as different hormones, activate cellular processes. The main aims of our project has been to develop and use powerful computational modeling for understanding the moleculear basis of the action of the above systems.

Intellectual Merit - Our previous studies developed methods for studying phosphate hydrolysis reactions in solution, in RasGAP, in EF-Tu and in ATPases. We explored the key role of mutations that lead to cancer and identified the underlined allosteric mechanism as well as the way chemical energy is converted to work. We performed major ab initio QM/MM studies of the reference solution reaction and evaluated the corresponding surface in G-proteins and ATPases. We also made major progress in studying the biological motors, F0F1-ATP synthase, and myosin V. Similarly, we made a major progress in CG modeling of GPCRs and the control of directionally by the proteasome.  

Broader Impact - Since being awarded the 2013 Nobel Prize in chemistry, the PI has become a science ambassador, delivering lectures in major forums and in special students and scientists motivation events. This includes the Lindau meeting and similar events around the globe. In these events he has been  giving general scientific lectures and then more focused Master Classes. He has also lectured to secondary school students about how science is developed over time. Before the Covid pandemic, he delivered, on average, two lectures a month, internationally, and today, continues to contribute via Zoom conferences. The PI and his coworkers have authored major reviews that can be used in graduate classwork on chemical biology. The PI also wrote a widely used book on enzyme simulations, that has been used in computation modeling classes. The PI co-developed key simulation methods for studies of biomolecules. The PI’s group generated movies on the nature of GTPase and ATPase reactions and theses movies have been used by various professors in their lectures. Finally, the simulation package MOLARIS-XG, which allows general EVB simulations and is publicly accessible. In considering the scientific impact of our project, we note that understanding the detailed action of G-proteins, ATPases and GCPRs can have far reaching impact on understanding cellular processes and can provide key clues for the design of anticancer drugs. Our simulations have provided insights into the action of G-proteins and have yielded an important element in the study of biological signal transduction. The focus on the systematic modeling of phosphoryl transfer in solution by ab initio approaches has drawn the attention of the theoretical community to the key problems in the field. Finally, the studies of allosteric effects in G-Proteins should eventually provide a better understanding of the control of signal transduction and help in the design of effective drugs against devastating diseases.
